course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Hong Kong Culture
course.description: Explores Hong Kong identity and urban space in the local-national-global nexus, the city's changing political cultures as well as various forms of cultural politics in civil society.

reviews.author: Orangeee
reviews.title: Good grade
reviews.comment_content: The content is about Hong Kong culture - identity, city space and popular culture. It is not easy for business students. Some content is pretty sensitive but Prof Ku provides a very open and safe environment for us to discuss.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Clear and professional teaching. I enjoy every class.

The course is taught in Cantonese with English written notes. You are allowed to use English or Chinese in assessments.
reviews.comment_grading: No statistics are provided but the grading is very good. I didn't revise much on the content for final exams, spend fair effort on the essays and get an A range surprisingly.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite tough. One short essay (500-800 words), one long essay (2500-3000 words), one group presentation (quite chill), and one final exam in essay format. Attendance is required for presentation sessions.

Readings are very important for essays and presentations.

reviews.author: ip
reviews.comment_content:
Hong Kong Culture that covered 1950s to present
interesting content, very up-to-date content with AEB movement in the last part
-formation of Hong Kong identity
-spatial development, places making, community
-political development
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was in Cantonese. It was clear and easy to follow. However, the ppt would not be uploaded. During the semester, we had lecture videos at first because its covid sem but then she removed the lecture vids towards the end of the lectures because the content taught was quite controversial probably.
One thing to note was that the content taught/ lecture notes served merely as a guide of exams/essays. It is really a must to read the readings if you want to follow her way to analyze during exams.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was really good, got A range, but no stats given.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty light.
-Attendance for seminars (seminars are like tutorials with one group presenting the reading materials +Q&A for participation marks) I personally spoke twice throughout the sem but still got a decent grade.
-Seminar presentation- Form your own groups and present the readings plus some analysis on a given question, pretty chill
-Short Assignment - 800 words on a given question. We were advised to closely refer to the reading written by the Prof. Interestingly, the question was the research question in the reading. Therefore, it was more of a reproduction of the given reading after thorough understanding of the arguments and the way she analyzed it.
-Essay - 2500 words in English/ 3000 words in Chinese on a given seminar question with guided readings given. You can even choose the one you presented. However, it was more than a reproduction. Some tips - have to build some arguments and fit the examples from the readings in the right place.
-Final exam - Exam was pretty chill. It was in essay format similar to the seminar questions.

reviews.author: rei
reviews.title: easy and good grade
reviews.comment_content: the content is about Hong Kong culture, not as easy as I thought. But the language used in Cantonese by professor definitely reduce the difficulty of learning the topic
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ku is passionate and humorous as well. Her friendly and nice personality motivates the student to participate in class. And she is willing to all the questions.
reviews.comment_grading: I didn't do all the reading and didn't revise the whole content for the midterm and exams. for the short and long essay, I didn't devote to them very much as well. But still, I think I got a good grade about B or B-. It is beyond my expectation to get such grade as I didn't pay much effort into it.
reviews.comment_workload: Reading a lot, but it is okay for you not to read. one short essay (very easy), and one long essay. one group presentation, which you can present in Cantonese. you have to go through very deeply and detailed for the presentation. take attendance merely in tutorial classes (student's presentation session). overall I think the workload is very acceptable.

reviews.author: Law~
reviews.title: Worth taking course!
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers 3 main areas -- Hong Kong Identity; Place and Space; and Political Culture of Hong Kong. The course introduces some theories in cultural studies and sociology which I found them highly beneficial for extra-curricular learning & reading later.

The professor will cover learning materials (summary of scholars' articles & current/historic affairs of Hong Kong) during lecture for each area of learning before holding seminars (students' presentation) where class discussion will take place. The lectures and class discussion were all conducted in Cantonese which you will find it comfortable and manageable!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very Good teaching! Always being clear, objective, and professional !!

Prof. Ku has been updating the course content and introducing new readings (at the same time phasing out some) when I compare the course syllabus of this course over these years.

During class discussion, the professor also summarized points raised by students and usually ended with some concluding remarks to consolidate our concepts and understandings towards the course content.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair and Good Grade! The understandings on cultural theories & interests in Hong Kong affairs will be an important factor determining your grade!
reviews.comment_workload:
It's okay in terms of workload -- but you will definitely enjoy the work if you are passionate to this course.

You will need to spend hour(s) before 9 seminar sessions to read and analyze the assigned readings to familiarize yourself with the topics (which will cover in final exam as well so you better finish it along the semester). Each seminar covers up to 5 readings (20 pages long each), some of them are written in English and other Chinese [around 50:50]

You will need to prepare one 1,000-word short essay and one 2,500-word long essay, in which it could take time to fully understand the assigned readings if you hope to write something insightful and impressive

Everyone needs to form groups to conduct a seminar presentation, which is 45 minutes long, with a 30-minutes Q&A afterwards

reviews.author: jackyjac
reviews.title: An Interesting Course
reviews.comment_content:
The course was about the culture of Hong Kong in regards of Identity, Cityspace and Politics. If you are interested in local affairs and political active, you will be passionate to attend the lectures.

Topics included: Hong Kong-Chinese conflicts, Spacing, Hegemony, 1st July March, Umbrella Movement, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor will explain details about each topic and engage student's thinking (as it is a social science course). It's like listening to stories about the development of Hong Kong from the 1950s. Notes will be provided in each lectures.

The course is taught in spoken Cantonese and written English.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was not bad for me. It's not the most important thing that I have concerned about this course, no statistics can be provided though.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not so heavy. One short (600-800 words) and one long essay (2000-3000 words). Final examination (essay questions) and a group seminar presentation. For the presentation, you have to read for several readings and present the content to the class plus some critical thinking.

You can use either Chinese or English to complete all of the assigned tasks.

Attendance will only be taken for seminar presentations.

reviews.author: eu
reviews.title: Learned a lot!
reviews.comment_content: The course is not about memorization, instead it leads u to understand basic sociology terms such as hegemony and apply them through writing essays(2 times for homework)and working on a group research project. My project title was political apathy which I find really thought-provoking when we relate our findings to the later umbrella movement... Quite a number of reading, it would be fine if you are interested in social issues and current news. Feel free to participate in in-class discussion in Cantonese!
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is a respectful scholar, one of the best in hkust.
reviews.comment_grading: Your effort will be paid accordingly.
reviews.comment_workload: Appropriate (especially if you like so sci)

reviews.author: Natsume
reviews.title: A fine course
reviews.comment_content:
changed a bit for this semester
the content was quite interesting, all about the Hong culture past and now
There are quite a lot of reading materials but in both Chinese and English, so it is not that convenient when you doing the presentation (which is presented in Cantonese but in English ppt)
reviews.comment_teaching:
using English notes but speaking in Cantonese
teaching content is a bit messy
Sometimes she even doesn't know what she is talking about.
reviews.comment_grading:
grading not bad
Homework essay put effort and time got B+
9 write the final
The final grade can still get B

Although the grading is not bad, I do not know what I have learned.
